children.value: InnerSelf is a tiny view + state management solution using innerHTML. Aims to mimic a React+Redux solution in a minimal way, at just 600 bytes minified, ~350 bytes when gzipped. This handy utility was written by
jam - a game dev competition where the whole game has to fit into 13KB!

From the readme,
InnerSelf is inspired by
. It offers the following familiar concepts:
and even an optional logging middleware for debugging!
It does all of this by serializing your component tree to a string and assigning it to
of a root element. It even imitates Virtual DOM diffing by comparing last known output of components with the new one!
Defining a component works as follows,
as a parameter, and returns a string. The return string is a processed tagged template literal. You can read more about it on the
is a function that takes in a template string and gives out a processed output string. So if
. This is the view part of the library.
Now the state management closely mimics Redux.
The state of your app resides in a
You pass a reducer while creating a store. A reducer is function that updates the state on dispatch of an event (done using
Let’s see how a sample reducer would look like,
// 'init' is the state of the application
// do some deletion, return updated state
on a dispatch of a custom event, the reducer is called to update the state. Once the reducer updates the state, the dom is re-rendered.
The components have access to the state when we “connect” them using the
function. The connect function makes the state available to the component function via function parameters. So when exporting the
We don’t export the component as-is, we return the “connected” component. Finally we attach the app to the root of the DOM node we want it to take control of
// App is a top level component
See the Pen TodoMVC Innerself by Cweili (@Cweili) on CodePen.
Here is a high level overview of how everything works together
Note that this is the user workflow once the App is attached to a DOM node and all necessary components are have been “connected”.
User presses a button (or some other interaction). An event is triggered by calling
Dispatch calls the reducer with the event type and arguments
Reducer takes the right action based on the event type and updates the state (well actually it returns the new state as a return value,
then updates it. But the net effect is the same)
Once the state has been updated,
processes the templates by calling the component function - a connected
returns the rendered string based on the current state. The rendering is recursive as each component can have a subcomponent. More on this later.
It then checks if the component has changed (as compared to current DOM), if not, nothing is done. If there is an update, the innerHTML is overwritten.
Note the performance drawbacks as unlike React which does an careful DOM diffing, InnerSelf just rewrites the whole DOM (which it is attached to).
All the core code resides in just one
file, just over 50 lines of code including comments. Talk about minimal!
The first part is the main rendering part, (If you’re not familiar with tagged template literals, I strongly suggest reading about it on the
// Weave the literal strings and the interpolations.
// We don't have to explicitly handle array-typed values
// because concat will spread them flat for us.
// Filter out interpolations which are bools, null or undefined.
function processes a template literal. This is known as a tagged template literal, where the “tag” (

)receives the template literal passed to it as a function parameter.
The first parameter is the source string split into an array, at the point of expressions in the string. So if there are
expressions in the template, you have an array of
strings. Next follows a variable length of parameters, each for one expression (relative position of expression is maintained).
takes in all the expression values, interleaves it with the string array. If you take the above example string, you’d have
Then filter out any falsey value, and then concatenate them into a string.
The second part and last part, handled by
// Poor man's Virtual DOM implementation :)  Compare the new output
// with the last output for this root.  Don't trust the current
// value of root.innerHTML as it may have been changed by other
// Dispatch an event on the root to give developers a chance to
// do some housekeeping after the whole DOM is replaced under
// the root. You can re-focus elements in the listener to this

, it maps a root to an component (generally the main app component). This just implies that the specific component is responsible for the given DOM element, all the rendered content goes under that DOM element.
functions mainly like a wrapper that takes the state and passes it on to the component function. You “connect” functions which need to access the global state to render the html string.
, which is called when you do an “attach”, or when there’s a event dispatched. The render function goes through every “root ↔ component” pair, and does the following -
Gets the rendered output for that component
Compares to the previously generated output for that DOM node
If the output is different, update
Dispatch a custom event in case the application needs to do some housekeeping

That is pretty much it, a very minimalistic and clean library to write small applications without loosing your sanity.
